item.title: Various Tools
item.description:
sent

  • tool for presentations
  • based on Takahashi method
  • minimal, easy to write

mathpix

  • screenshot of any equation to LaTeX
  • unfortunately only for Mac and mobiles There is a small workaround for Linux. Mathpix is based on an API that you can call up to 1000 times per month for free. So just get an API key, create a file eqtotex.py
#!/usr/bin/env python

# imports
import sys
import base64
import requests
import json

# file path of picture
file_path = str(sys.argv[1]);

# request api
image_uri = "data:image/jpg;base64," + base64.b64encode(open(file_path, "rb").read())
r = requests.post("https://api.mathpix.com/v3/latex",
    data=json.dumps({'src': image_uri}),
    headers={"app_id": "YOUR_APP_ID", "app_key": "YOUR_APP_KEY",
            "Content-type": "application/json"})
data = json.loads(r.text);

# print latex code
print data['latex']

and for laziness create a bash script called eq2tex in your PATH

#!/bin/bash

# execute python script with file as argument (e.g. eq.jpg)
echo `python2 /path/to/eqtotex.py $1`

Then if you have a picture of an equation, let’s say testeq.jpg, simply type into the terminal

$ eq2tex /path/to/testeq.jpg

and the LaTeX code of that equation is printed into the terminal.

item.title: Academic Library Management Done Right
item.description:
It is really useful to keep a central place where you put all interesting things you find on the internet like Books, Websites, Articles, … . For me this central place is Zotero.

How my library is organized

I like keeping four sublibraries for

  • textbooks
  • my own calculations, transcripts and reviews
  • papers, articles, theses and similar
  • websites

in which I don’t have any further ordering.

Adding a new entry

The feature I like most about Zotero is the Zotero Connector. It’s an addon for firefox, that automatically senses content, so you can add it to Zotero with just one click. This is how I add new papers, books or websites usually.

In the other case I just add them manually to Zotero.

Citing in Latex

When I’m writing down some calculation or a draft I also need to reference work performed by others. I usually keep a long .bibtex file in some directory, which I’m linking in the .tex file of the calculation, draft or else. Any .bibtex file can be easily created with Zotero using Export > (Choose Better BibTex).

Citing other work could then look like this \cite{egerland17}. The short and more easy to handle label for a citation is called a bibtex key and there is a nice add-on in Zotero called Better BibTex which automatically generates them. My citation key format is [auth:lower][shortyear].

A central place for the files / Synchronization

One can synchronize the Zotero library if one creates an account. However a disadvantage of that is, that only the information, not necessarily the papers etc. get synchronized/backupped. Zotero also has the slight flaw of introducing its own storage system that is not just one folder with all the .pdfs and so on crammed into it.

A nice workaround for that is again an add-on, this one’s called Zotfile. It basically syncs the .pdfs to a folder that can be synchronized with other computers, e.g. a dropbox or owncloud folder.

I really like and use this add-on to have my papers and books with me on all my devices (PC at home, laptop, tablet, …).

item.title: How To: This Website
item.description:
I have been searching long and wide for an easy to make and easy to maintain website. Most things sucked until I found out about R Markdown Websites. You basically write your content in markdown and then R Markdown handles everything for you. It was certainly a way to do it and for everyone who wants to try I can recommend:

  • Nick Strayer

  • Robert Mitchell

There were however some issues that bothered me. I couldn’t get the page to look the way I wanted it to look (which is probably my fault) and building the website took quite long, i.e. up to a minute. The webpage stood still for a couple of months until I discovered Hugo, which for now is the perfect solution for me.

Getting Started

The Quick Start shows how to install Hugo and deploy a first website with it. Just like my last webpage, this page is hosted on GitHub and there’s a nice manual on how to deploy Hugo as a GitHub Page. Furthermore I’m using the Academic Theme on this site (with some small modifications).

Managing Content

My workflow on this websites consists of starting the webpage with

$ hugo server

All the content is written in markdown files, which are easy to read and edit (for a good markdown tutorial see commonmark).

I add content, change content and reiterate until I’m happy. Saving the markdown files automatically rebuilds the site, so I can instantly see the changes.

To finish it off I’m using a script to deploy the page to GitHub.

$ ./deploy.sh "Commit message"

Icons in Hugo

I am using my favorite icon set Font Awesome. To incorporate them in Hugo one has to add

<script defer src="https://use.fontawesome.com/releases/v5.2.0/js/all.js" integrity="sha384-4oV5EgaV02iISL2ban6c/RmotsABqE4yZxZLcYMAdG7FAPsyHYAPpywE9PJo+Khy" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>

in /themes/YOUR_THEME/layouts/partials/header.html. There is also another way to embed icons, which I did not follow, mainly because I did not understand it.

To use font awesome also as the icon of the webpage (the small atom) I used fa2png.
